svcsubproc.title: Programmable Parameters
svcsubproc.para: Certain programmable parameters that affect the engine electronic control systems may be changed with electronic service tools (see Electronic Service Tools ). The parameters are stored in the system Electronic Control Module (ECM) and are protected from unauthorized change by passwords.The programmable parameters are either "System Parameters" or "Customer Parameters."

System Configuration Parameters are set at the factory and affect emissions or horsepower ratings within a family of engines. Factory passwords must be obtained and used to change System Configuration Parameters.

Customer Selectable Parameters are variable, and are used to specify operating parameters for: cruise control, PTO operation, vehicle speed limits, progressive shifting, type of engine protection system, RPM and horsepower ratings within the engine family. Customer passwords must be used to change Customer Parameters.

Since each control system is electronically programmable to individual owner specifications, the operating parameters will vary from vehicle to vehicle. Some of these parameters may cause the engine to operate in a way that the driver (or service technician) does not expect, if proper training has not taken place. This may lead to power or performance complaints and/or service time, when the engine is operating correctly.
EXAMPLE: If the driver attempts to drive 60 mph and the vehicle speed limiting option has been programmed to limit vehicle speed to 55 mph, the driver may complain of low power.

svcsubproc.title: Passwords
svcsubproc.para: "System Configuration Parameters" are protected by Caterpillar factory passwords. Factory passwords are only available to authorized Caterpillar dealers.
"Customer Parameters" are protected by customer passwords. The customer pass- words are selected by the customer and can be changed using electronic service tools.
For complete information on passwords, refer to the appropriate Caterpillar Service Manuals.

svcsubproc.title: Self-Diagnostics
svcsubproc.para: Caterpillar Electronic Engine Control systems have some ability to diagnose their own circuits. When a problem condition is detected, a diagnostic code is generated and the Engine Warning light on the instrument panel may be turned ON (not all codes cause the light to come ON). In most cases, the code is also logged (stored) in the ECM permanent memory. This memory is not lost when turning the vehicle off or when disconnecting the batteries.
Codes representing current conditions are called ACTIVE codes. They indicate that a problem of some kind currently exists. They should always be serviced.

If a fault condition occurred and caused a code to be logged, but is no longer present, the code is referred to as an INACTIVE code. This can occur with an intermittent condition or even if repairs were made, but the code was not cleared. Logged INACTIVE codes don't necessarily mean that something requires service. They are meant to be an indicator of intermittent conditions. In addition, some logged codes record events, and not faults.
Intermittent codes that don't require a password to clear are automatically cleared after 100 hours of ECM operation, if the condition does not happen again.
When an ACTIVE code is logged, the Engine Warning light is turned ON.
